Evidence: Limited to small-scale studies; FDA-approved for transplant/cancer but early stage for geroscience.
Reference: Mannick JB, et al., 2014, Sci Transl Med, doi:10.1126/scitranslmed.3009892.

Evidence: FDA-approved but chronic use has moderate risks; high doses cause side effects like metabolic disturbances, stomatitis, and impaired wound healing.
Reference: Kaeberlein M, 2014, J Genet Genomics, doi:10.1016/j.jgg.2014.06.009.

Evidence: Gold standard evidence; NIA ITP confirmed significant median and maximal lifespan extension (up to 28%) in mice, even when started late in life.
Reference: Miller RA, Harrison, et al., 2014, Aging Cell, doi:10.1111/acel.12194.

Evidence: Gold standard evidence; NIA ITP confirmed significant median and maximal lifespan extension (up to 28%) in mice, even when started late in life.
Reference: Harrison, D. E., et al., 2009, Nature, doi:10.1038/nature08221

Evidence: Broad and potent benefits; delays cognitive decline, cardiac dysfunction, and immune senescence.
Reference: Bitto, A., et al., 2016, eLife, doi:10.7554/eLife.16351

Evidence: mTOR pathway is a master regulator of metabolism, ubiquitously and highly conserved from yeast to humans.
Reference: Saxton RA et al., 2017, Cell, doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.02.004

Evidence: Direct, non-invasive biomarker pS6K can be measured in peripheral blood to show target engagement.
Reference: Liao, C. et al., 2012, Anticancer Research, PMID: 23060538

Evidence: Moderate cost as a generic prescription drug.
Reference: Taber, D. J., et al., 2015, Current Opinion in Organ Transplantation, doi:10.1007/s40472-015-0052-y

Evidence: Vast indirect evidence from 60+ years of use; retrospective studies show lower all-cause mortality; prospective TAME trial is pending.
Reference: Barzilai N, et al., 2016, Cell Metab, doi:10.1016/j.cmet.2016.05.011.

Evidence: Unparalleled safety; on WHO Essential Medicines list, used by >150M people. Lactic acidosis is extremely rare.
Reference: Flory JH & Lipska K, 2019, JAMA, doi:10.1001/jama.2019.11708.

Evidence: Inconsistent; extends invertebrate lifespan, but multiple mouse studies (including NIA ITP) failed to show a significant/reproducible effect.
Reference: Strong, R., et al., 2016, Aging Cell, doi: 10.1111/acel.12496

Evidence: More consistent than lifespan; improves physical performance, insulin sensitivity, and cognitive function in non-human primates.
Reference: Kodali, M., et al., 2021, Aging Cell, doi:10.1111/acel.13277

Evidence: Primary target, AMPK, is an exceptionally conserved central regulator of cellular energy metabolism across all eukaryotes.
Reference: Hardie DG, et al., 2012, Nat Rev Mol Cell Biol, doi:10.1038/nrm3368.

Evidence: No direct geroscience-specific biomarker; relies on downstream metabolic outcomes (e.g., blood glucose, HbA1c).
Reference: Mueller, N. T., et al., 2021, Diabetes Care, doi:10.2337/dc20-2257

Evidence: Highly accessible; available as a generic drug for pennies a day.
Reference: Soukas AA, et al., 2019, Annu Rev Med, doi:10.1146/annurev-med-050217-054734.

Evidence: Vast evidence from decades of use for diabetes/prediabetes; trials show it can prevent diabetes progression and reduce cardiovascular events.
Reference: DiNicolantonio JJ, et al., 2015, Open Heart, doi:10.1136/openhrt-2015-000327

Evidence:
Most common side effects are mild, transient GI issues.
Standard dosing of 25-100 mg three times daily with meals causes gastrointestinal side effects, with 74% of patients reporting flatulence in a US trial
Reference: Chiasson J, et al., 2003, JAMA,  doi:10.1001/jama.290.4.486

Evidence:
Most common side effects are mild, transient GI issues.
Standard dosing of 25-100 mg three times daily with meals causes gastrointestinal side effects, with 74% of patients reporting flatulence in a US trial
Reference: STOP-NIDDM trial., 2003, JAMA, doi:10.1001/jama.290.4.486.

Evidence: Powerful and rigorously validated; NIA ITP found it extended median lifespan of male mice by 16-22% but 5% in females.
Reference: Harrison DE et al., 2014, Aging Cell, 10.1111/acel.12170

Evidence: Powerful and rigorously validated; NIA ITP found it extended median lifespan of male mice by 16-22% but 5% in females.
Reference: Harrison DE et al., 2019, Aging Cell, doi:10.1111/acel.12898

Evidence: Notable benefits in mice including improved metabolic health, diminished liver degeneration, and beneficial modulation of gut microbiota.
Reference: Harrison DE et al., 2019, Aging Cell, doi:10.1111/acel.12898

Evidence: Primary mechanism (inhibition of alpha-glucosidase) and downstream effects on aging pathways (GLP-1, IGF-I) are highly conserved across mammals.
Reference: Harrison DE et al., 2019, Aging Cell, doi:10.1111/acel.12898

Evidence: Clinical effects are easily monitored using standard metabolic biomarkers like blood glucose and HbA1c.
Reference: Holman RR, et al., 2017, The Lancet Diabetes & Endocrinology, doi:10.1016/S2213-8587(17)30309-1

Evidence: Highly accessible as a low-cost, widely available generic drug.
Reference: DiNicolantonio JJ, et al, 2015, Open Heart, doi:10.1136/openhrt-2015-000327

Evidence: FDA-approved for diabetes/obesity. Large trials show reduced cardiovascular events. Semaglutide shown to reduce epigenetic age.
Reference: Marso SP, et al., 2016, N Engl J Med, doi:10.1056/NEJMoa1607141

Evidence: FDA-approved for diabetes/obesity. Large trials show reduced cardiovascular events. Semaglutide shown to reduce epigenetic age.
Reference: Corley MJ, et al., 2024, Nat Commun, doi:10.1038/s41467-024-51772-5.

Evidence: Well-characterized profile, but side effects like nausea and vomiting can be significant.
Demonstrates significant benefits for cardiovascular health, neuroprotection, and metabolic function in animal models.
Reference: Zheng Z et al., 2024, Signal Transduction and Targeted Therapy, doi:10.1038/s41392-024-01931-z.

Evidence: Broad benefits: improved cardiovascular health, reduced hepatic fat, and potential neuroprotective effects.
Reference: Somineni HK, 2014, J Endocrinol, doi:10.1530/JOE-13-0532.

Evidence: Highly conserved pathway in metabolic control (brain, heart, pancreas); mimics endogenous hormone GLP-1.
Reference: Drucker DJ, 2018, Cell Metab, doi:10.1016/j.cmet.2018.03.001

Evidence: Modulates validated epigenetic biomarkers of aging. Metabolic markers (blood glucose, body composition) also available.
Reference:
Corley MJ, et al., 2025, medRxiv
 [Preprint], doi:10.1101/2025.07.09.25331038.

Evidence: High cost (~$12,000/year) and inaccessible for many.
Reference: Lin T, et al., 2024, Ann Intern Med, doi:10.7326/M23-2736.

Evidence: Exceptionally strong evidence; FDA-approved for heart failure and chronic kidney disease, preventing major age-related diseases.
Reference: Packer M, et al., 2020, N Engl J Med, doi:10.1056/NEJMoa2024816.

Evidence: Excellent profile; side effects (increased urination, genital infections) are manageable and often transient.
Reference: Neal B, et al., 2017, N Engl J Med, doi:10.1056/NEJMoa1611925

Evidence: NIA ITP found a 14% median lifespan extension in male mice, but benefits appear confined to males.
Reference: Snyder JM, et al., 2023, Geroscience, doi:10.1007/s11357-022-00641-0.

Evidence: Broad benefits in animal models: reduced visceral fat, preserved lean mass, and mitigation of cardiomyopathy and kidney disease.
Reference: Snyder, J.M., et al., 2023, GeroScience, doi:10.1007/s11357-022-00641-0

Evidence: Pleiotropic and highly conserved mechanisms, including modulation of mTOR/AMPK and the NLRP3 inflammasome.
Reference: Yesilyurt-Dirican Z et al., 2025, npj Aging and Mechanisms of Disease, doi:10.1038/s41514-025-00227-y

Evidence: Reliably reduces inflammatory markers (IL-6) and clinical biomarkers of renal and heart failure (eGFR, NT-pro-BNP).
Reference: Yoo TT et al., 2025, Cardiovascular Diabetology, doi:10.1186/s12933-025-02777-7

Evidence: Moderate cost as branded prescription drugs.
Reference: Aggarwal R et al., 2022, Circulation: Heart Failure, doi:10.1161/CIRCHEARTFAILURE.121.009099

Evidence: No human trial data for geroscience; a human trial assessing AKG's effect on biological age is in progress.
Reference: Sandalova E et al., 2023, Geroscience, doi:10.1007/s11357-023-00813-6,

Evidence: Considered Generally Recognized as Safe (GRAS) by the FDA; preclinical study in mice found no significant adverse effects.
Reference: Asadi Shahmirzadi A, et al., 2020, Cell Metab, doi:10.1016/j.cmet.2020.08.004.

Evidence: Consistently extends lifespan in invertebrates; key mouse study showed 12% median lifespan extension, more pronounced in females.
Reference: Asadi Shahmirzadi A, et al., 2020, Cell Metab, doi:10.1016/j.cmet.2020.08.004.

Evidence: Compresses morbidity in aged mice, improving frailty index by over 40% and enhancing physical function.
Reference: Asadi Shahmirzadi A, et al., 2020, Cell Metab, doi:10.1016/j.cmet.2020.08.004.

Evidence: Highly conserved as a fundamental metabolite in the TCA cycle, contributing to metabolism, collagen synthesis, and epigenetic regulation.
Reference: Wu N et al., 2016, Biomolecules & Therapeutics, doi:10.4062/biomolther.2015.078.

Evidence: No established geroscience-specific biomarker; plasma AKG levels are not a validated biomarker for its anti-aging effect.
Reference: Sandalova E et al., 2023, Geroscience, doi:10.1007/s11357-023-00813-6.

Evidence: Highly accessible; widely available as a low-cost over-the-counter supplement.
Reference: Demidenko O, et al., 2021, Aging (Albany NY), doi:10.18632/aging.203736.

Evidence: Preliminary; early-phase trials show reduced senescent cell burden and improved physical function in patients with specific diseases.
Reference: Hickson LJ et al., 2019, EBioMedicine, doi:10.1016/j.ebiom.2019.08.069.

Evidence: Key concern as Dasatinib is a powerful chemotherapy drug; long-term effects of intermittent dosing are unknown.
Reference: Rad AN et al., 2024, Current Drug Metabolism, doi:10.1016/j.mad.2023.111888

Evidence: Positive but modest; pharmacological clearance with D+Q increased median lifespan in mice by ~6.3% in one key study.
Reference: Blagosklonny MV, 2021, Oncotarget, doi:10.18632/oncotarget.28049.

Evidence: Primary strength; broad and impressive effects, improving cardiovascular function, osteoporosis, physical, and cognitive performance.
Reference: Wyatt AW et al., 2021, Annual Review of Pharmacology and Toxicology,  doi:10.1146/annurev-pharmtox-050120-105018

Evidence: Cellular senescence is a highly conserved biological process in vertebrates.
Reference: Davaapil H et al., 2017, Development, doi:10.1242/dev.138222

Evidence: Major barrier; lacks a simple, non-invasive biomarker. Assessment typically requires invasive tissue biopsies (p16INK4a, SA-β-gal).
Reference: Muthamil S et al., 2024, Advanced Biology, doi:10.1002/adbi.202400079

Evidence: Likely to be high cost due to the inclusion of Dasatinib, a chemotherapy drug.
Reference: Rad AN et al., 2024, Current Drug Metabolism, doi:10.1016/j.mad.2023.111888

Evidence: Early stages; trials are underway for frailty, but no definitive results for an anti-aging indication exist.
Reference: Yousefzadeh MJ et al., 2018, eBioMedicine, doi:10.1016/j.ebiom.2018.09.015

Evidence: Major advantage; as a natural compound in food, it is generally considered safe for human use.
Reference: Yousefzadeh MJ et al., 2018, eBioMedicine, doi:10.1016/j.ebiom.2018.09.015

Evidence: Extended mouse lifespan by ~10% in one study, but contested by NIA ITP testing which found no effect.
Reference: Yousefzadeh MJ, et al., 2018, EBioMedicine, doi:10.1016/j.ebiom.2018.09.015.

Evidence: Benefits are broad-acting; studies show it can prevent cognitive decline, reduce inflammation, and improve metabolic health in animal models.
Reference: Pal HC et al., 2016, Advances in Experimental Medicine and Biology, doi:10.1007/978-3-319-41334-1_10

Evidence: Acts as a senolytic by clearing senescent cells and inhibiting SASP; also modulates highly conserved PI3K/AKT/mTOR and SIRT1 pathways.
Reference: Tavenier et al., 2024, Mechanisms of Ageing and Development, 10.1016/j.mad.2024.111995

Evidence: Significant challenge; lacks a simple, non-invasive biomarker for senescent cell burden.
Reference: Ogrodnik M et al., 2024, Cell, doi:10.1016/j.cell.2024.05.059

Evidence: Highly accessible due to low cost and widespread availability as an over-the-counter supplement.
Reference: Yousefzadeh MJ, et al., 2018, EBioMedicine, doi:10.1016/j.ebiom.2018.09.015.

Evidence: Growing evidence from small trials confirms safety and efficacy in increasing blood NAD+ levels; reported benefits in muscle insulin sensitivity and walking endurance.
Reference: Yoshino M, et al., 2021, Science, doi:10.1126/science.abe9985.

Evidence: Excellent safety profile; multiple human trials found supplements to be safe and well-tolerated with no significant adverse events.
Reference: Berven et al., 2023, Nature Communications, doi:10.1038/s41467-023-43514-6

Evidence: NR did not extend lifespan in NIA ITP mouse studies. NMN extended median lifespan by 8.5%, but only in female mice.
Reference: Harrison et al., 2021, Aging Cell, doi:10.1111/acel.13328

Evidence: Stronger evidence than for lifespan; numerous rodent studies show amelioration of age-associated declines in insulin sensitivity, vascular health, and physical endurance.
Reference: Rajman et al., 2018, Cell Metabolism, doi:10.1016/j.cmet.2018.01.008

Evidence: Major strength; NAD+ metabolism is a fundamental and ancient biochemical process conserved across all domains of life.
Reference: Belenky et al., 2007, Trends in Biochemical Sciences

Evidence: The primary goal of boosting NAD+ is a direct, measurable, and non-invasive biomarker via whole blood concentrations.
Reference: Martens CR, et al., 2018, Nat Commun, doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03421-7.

Evidence: Available as over-the-counter supplements at a moderate cost.
Reference: McDermott et al., 2024, Nature Communications, doi:10.1038/s41467-024-49092-5

Evidence: Promising but preliminary; human trials report positive outcomes in muscle strength and endurance.
Reference: Liu et al., 2022, JAMA Network Open, doi:10.1001/jamanetworkopen.2021.44279

Evidence: Strong safety profile; no serious adverse events reported in human trials.
Reference: Andreux et al., 2019, Nature Metabolism, doi:10.1038/s42255-019-0073-4

Evidence: Limited but promising; one key study found a 45% increase in lifespan in C. elegans and improved rodent healthspan.
Reference: Ryu et al., 2016, Nature Medicine, doi:10.1038/nm.4132

Evidence: Broad benefits including anti-inflammatory, antioxidant, and anti-aging properties; improves muscle function and delays fatigue in animal models.
Reference: D’Amico et al., 2021, Trends in Molecular Medicine, doi:10.1016/j.molmed.2021.04.009

Evidence: Based on activating mitophagy, a highly conserved cellular cleanup process for removing damaged mitochondria.
Reference: Faitg et al., 2023, Calcified Tissue International, doi:10.1007/s00223-023-01145-5

Evidence: A challenge; a simple, non-invasive biomarker of its primary effect (mitophagy) is not yet routinely available, but plasma acylcarnitines have been used.
Reference: Liu et al., 2022, JAMA Network Open, doi:10.1001/jamanetworkopen.2021.44279

Evidence: Barrier; branded, clinically-tested formulations are often expensive.
Reference: Kuerec et al., 2024, Ageing Research Reviews, doi:10.1016/j.arr.2024.102406

Evidence: Limited to specific rare diseases (e.g., Barth syndrome); primary endpoints have not always been met.
Reference: Thompson et al., 2021, Genetics in Medicine, doi:10.1038/s41436-020-01006-8

Evidence: Strength; well-tolerated in trials, with the most common side effects being mild injection-site reactions.
Reference: Karaa et al., 2023, Neurology, doi:10.1212/WNL.0000000000207402

Evidence: Lack of explicit lifespan data, but improves physiological function in aging mouse models.
Reference: Chiao et al., 2020, eLife, doi:10.7554/eLife.55513

Evidence: Strong benefits in preclinical models, including improved cardiac and skeletal muscle function and rescued muscle force in aging mice.
Reference: Campbell et al., 2019, Free Radical Biology and Medicine, doi:10.1016/j.freeradbiomed.2018.12.031

Evidence: Highly conserved; targets cardiolipin in the inner mitochondrial membrane to stabilize cristae, reduce oxidative stress, and enhance ATP production.
Reference: Szeto, 2014, British Journal of Pharmacology, doi:10.1111/bph.12461

Evidence: Functional benefits in mice occurred without detectable changes in epigenetic or transcriptomic age, indicating these clocks do not measure its effect.
Reference: Mitchell et al., 2025, Aging Cell, doi:10.1111/acel.70026

Evidence: Expected to be prohibitively high as an investigational drug requiring injection.
Reference: Sabbah, 2022, Cardiovascular Drugs and Therapy, doi:10.1007/s10741-021-10177-8

Evidence: Early phases; small studies suggest improved cognitive skills in older adults, but larger trials are needed.
Reference: Wirth et al., 2018, Cortex, doi:10.1016/j.cortex.2018.09.014

Evidence: Major advantage; excellent safety profile as a natural polyamine found in food; well-tolerated.
Reference: Schwarz et al., 2018, Aging (Albany NY), doi:10.18632/aging.101354

Evidence: Prolongs lifespan in a wide array of organisms including yeast, flies, worms, and mice.
Reference: Eisenberg et al., 2016, Nature Medicine, doi:10.1038/nm.4222

Evidence: Strong effects, particularly on cardiac and brain function; higher dietary intake correlated with lower incidence of cardiovascular diseases in humans.
Reference: LaRocca et al., 2013, Mechanisms of Ageing and Development, doi:10.1016/j.mad.2013.04.004

Evidence: Highly conserved; induces autophagy, a fundamental cellular cleanup process, by inhibiting the acetyltransferase EP300.
Reference: Pietrocola et al., 2015, Cell Death & Differentiation, doi:10.1038/cdd.2014.215

Evidence: Key challenge; lacks a simple, routine biomarker for measuring autophagy in a clinical setting.
Reference: Klionsky et al., 2021, Autophagy (Guidelines, 4th ed.), doi:10.1080/15548627.2020.1797280

Evidence: Highly accessible due to low cost and widespread availability as an over-the-counter supplement.
Reference: Madeo et al., 2018, Autophagy Reviews (Perspective), doi: 10.1126/science.aan2788

Evidence: Large body of data from malaria/autoimmune use, but none for a geroscience indication.
Reference: Nirk EL et al., 2020, EMBO Molecular Medicine, doi:10.15252/emmm.202012476

Evidence: Major barrier; substantial side effect profile including potential neuromyopathy, retinopathy, and serious heart rhythm problems.
Reference: Bansal P et al., 2021, Annals of Medicine, doi:10.1080/07853890.2020.1839959

Evidence: Modest lifespan extension in middle-aged male mice; effects appear to be sex and age-dependent.
Reference: Doeppner TR et al., 2022, Aging (Albany NY), doi:10.18632/aging.204069

Evidence: Detrimental; emulates aging on the neuromuscular system, causing denervation and decreased muscle force in mice.
Reference: Saldarriaga CA et al., 2023, Journal of Applied Physiology, doi:10.1152/japplphysiol.00365.2023

Evidence: Conserved across eukaryotes; inhibits autophagy by preventing autophagosome-lysosome fusion.
No established, non-invasive biomarkers exist for its geroscience effects.
Reference: Klionsky DJ et al., 2021, Autophagy (Guidelines), doi:10.1080/15548627.2020.1797280

Evidence: Low cost as a generic drug, but this is irrelevant given its detrimental effects.
Reference: Kamat S et al., 2021, Frontiers in Pharmacology, doi:10.3389/fphar.2021.576093

Evidence: Promising but preliminary; a small, placebo-controlled trial found it was safe and improved a suite of age-associated abnormalities.
Reference: Kumar P et al., 2023, Journals of Gerontology Series A, doi:10.1093/gerona/glac135

Evidence: Human trial reported it was "safe and well-tolerated" with "no adverse events".
Reference: Lizzo G et al., 2022, Frontiers in Aging, doi:10.3389/fragi.2022.852569

Evidence: Limited direct studies, but individual components (glycine) have extended lifespan in mice.
Reference: Miller RA et al., 2019, Aging Cell, doi:10.1111/acel.12953

Evidence: Improves a range of age-related defects in mice (oxidative stress, mitochondrial function, insulin resistance); also improved physical function in a human trial.
Reference: Kumar P et al., 2021, Clinical and Translational Medicine, doi:10.1002/ctm2.372

Evidence: Based on a fundamental and highly conserved biochemical process: replenishing glutathione to protect mitochondria from oxidative stress.
Reference: Marí M et al., 2020, Antioxidants, doi:10.3390/antiox9100909

Evidence: Major advantage; the primary goal of correcting glutathione deficiency can be reliably quantified in blood and muscle.
Reference: Kumar P et al., 2023, Journals of Gerontology Series A, doi:10.1093/gerona/glac135

Evidence: Highly accessible as a low-cost nutritional supplement.
Reference: Sekhar RV et al., 2022, Antioxidants, doi:10.3390/antiox11010154

Evidence: Non-existent for a geroscience indication.
Reference: Manda et al., 2020, Frontiers in Pharmacology, doi:10.3389/fphar.2020.00151

Evidence: Concern; high doses may cause liver and kidney toxicity.
NIA ITP studies showed 8-10% median lifespan extension in male mice, but highly sex-specific with no benefit in females.
Reference: Harrison et al., 2014, Aging Cell, doi:10.1111/acel.12170

Evidence: Improved neuromuscular performance and physical function in both sexes.
Reference: Tezil et al., 2019, npj Aging and Mechanisms of Disease, doi:10.1038/s41514-019-0037-7

Evidence: Based on potent antioxidant/anti-inflammatory properties via conserved pathways (e.g., Nrf2/ARE) in mammals.
Reference: Rojo et al., 2012, Free Radical Biology and Medicine, doi:10.1016/j.freeradbiomed.2011.11.003

Evidence: No established biomarkers for its geroscience effects exist in humans.
Reference: Moqri et al., 2023, Cell, doi:10.1016/j.cell.2023.08.003

Evidence: Likely inexpensive, but use is limited by safety concerns and lack of human data.
Reference: John et al., 2020, Current Cancer Drug Targets, doi:10.2174/1568009619666191022141547

Evidence: Non-existent for a longevity intervention.
Reference: Stout et al., 2023, GeroScience, doi:10.1007/s11357-023-00767-9

Evidence: Limited safety context from topical use for hair loss; long-term systemic safety in healthy humans is largely unknown.
Reference: Kim et al., 2012, Annals of Dermatology, doi:10.5021/ad.2012.24.3.295

Evidence: 19% median lifespan extension in male mice in an NIA ITP study; effect was highly sex-specific.
Reference: Harrison et al., 2021, Aging Cell, doi:10.1111/acel.13328

Evidence: Prevented age-associated sarcopenia and fat gain in male mice without feminizing side effects; improved late-life physical function.
Reference: Garratt et al., 2019, Aging Cell, doi:10.1111/acel.12920

Evidence: Unique non-genomic anti-aging mechanism via membrane estrogen receptors, activating protein kinase cascades and producing epigenetic effects.
Reference: Arnal et al., 2017, Physiological Reviews, doi:10.1152/physrev.00024.2016

Evidence: No established biomarkers for its geroscience effects exist.
Reference: Justice et al., 2018, GeroScience, doi:10.1007/s11357-018-0042-y

Evidence: Likely inexpensive to produce, but would require a prescription and monitoring.
Reference: Ramos et al., 2023, Anais Brasileiros de Dermatologia, doi:10.1016/j.abd.2022.09.006

Evidence: Vast indirect evidence from long-term use for Parkinson's disease; no clinical study on healthy human aging.
Reference: Jost WH et al., 2022, Journal of Neural Transmission, doi:10.1007/s00702-022-02465-w

Evidence: Generally well-tolerated at low doses used for Parkinson's; high doses carry risk of interactions.
Reference: Wang K et al., 2023, Frontiers in Aging Neuroscience, doi:10.3389/fnagi.2023.1134472

Evidence: Meta-analysis of 22 rodent studies showed significant and reproducible lifespan extension.
Reference: Bene MR et al., 2025, Ageing Research Reviews, doi:10.1016/j.arr.2025.102873

Evidence: Neuroprotective effects; improves aspects of age-related hearing loss in mice; has antioxidant and anti-apoptotic effects.
Reference: Szepesy J et al., 2021, International Journal of Molecular Sciences, doi:10.3390/ijms22062853

Evidence: Conserved mechanism of irreversible inhibition of monoamine oxidase B (MAO-B), an enzyme in dopamine metabolism.
Reference: Tan YY et al., 2022, Journal of Parkinson’s Disease, doi:10.3233/JPD-212976

Evidence: MAO-B activity and dopamine metabolites can be measured, but aging-specific biomarkers are limited.
Reference: Justice JN et al., 2018, GeroScience, doi:10.1007/s11357-018-0042-y

Evidence: Low-cost and widely accessible as an approved, generic drug.
Reference: Dorsey ER et al., 2009, Neurology, doi:10.1212/WNL.0b013e3181ae7b04

Evidence: Entirely preclinical; first-in-human trials are beginning for specific indications like vision loss.
Reference: Yücel et al., 2024, Nature Communications, doi:10.1038/s41467-024-46020-5

Evidence: Greatest concern; continuous expression can lead to teratoma formation/cancer; delivery via viral vectors carries risks.
Reference: Abad et al., 2013, Nature, doi:10.1038/nature12586

Evidence: Most dramatic of all interventions; landmark study showed a 109% extension of remaining median lifespan in very old mice.
Reference: Cano Macip et al., 2024, Cellular Reprogramming, doi:10.1089/cell.2023.0072

Evidence: Dramatic effects; significant improvement in frailty index and functional rejuvenation in specific tissues.
Reference: Cano Macip et al., 2024, Cellular Reprogramming, doi:10.1089/cell.2023.0072

Evidence: Based on the highly conserved nature of epigenetic regulation across all eukaryotic life.
Reference: Allis et al., 2016, Nature Reviews Genetics, doi:10.1038/nrg.2016.59

Evidence: Strength; DNA methylation-based epigenetic clocks provide a direct, quantitative measure of age reversal.
Reference: Horvath et al., 2018, Nature Reviews Genetics, doi:10.1038/s41576-018-0004-3

Evidence: Prohibitively high; current delivery via viral vectors can cost over $1 million per dose.
Reference: Johnson et al., 2023, Nature Biotechnology, doi:10.1038/s41587-023-01760-5

Evidence: No human trial data for geroscience indication.
Reference: Wang J et al., 2023, Cell Stem Cell, doi:10.1016/j.stem.2023.08.001

Evidence: Unproven for systemic use; small molecules are safer than transgenic methods as they don't integrate into the genome, but systemic use requires thorough testing.
Reference: Kim Y et al., 2020, Experimental & Molecular Medicine, doi:10.1038/s12276-020-0383-3

Evidence: No direct evidence in mammals; one study showed lifespan and healthspan extension in C. elegans.
Reference: Schoenfeldt L et al., 2025, EMBO Molecular Medicine, doi:10.1038/s44321-025-00265-9

Evidence: Lacks direct healthspan data for mammalian models, but reverses cellular aging markers in human cells.
Reference: Yang JH et al., 2023, Aging (Albany NY), doi:10.18632/aging.204896

Evidence: Strong theoretical basis; targets highly conserved fundamental mechanisms like DNA methylation and histone modification.
Reference: Allis CD et al., 2016, Nature Reviews Genetics, doi:10.1038/nrg.2016.59

Evidence: Availability of epigenetic clocks provides a direct and quantitative biomarker for measuring its effects.
Reference: Horvath S et al., 2018, Nature Reviews Genetics, doi:10.1038/s41576-018-0004-3

Evidence: Likely to be high-cost and require specialist administration, though potentially cheaper than viral vectors.
Reference: Kim Y et al., 2020, Experimental & Molecular Medicine, doi:10.1038/s12276-020-0383-3

Evidence: Purely preclinical for geroscience, with no human trials underway.
Reference: Lelarge et al., 2024, npj Aging, doi:10.1038/s41514-024-00138-4

Evidence: Entirely unknown; risk of off-target effects and autoimmune reactions is a major concern.
Reference: Lelarge et al., 2024, npj Aging, doi:10.1038/s41514-024-00138-4

Evidence: Preclinical studies show a senolytic CAR-T cell therapy can improve aging phenotypes, but no direct lifespan data is available.
Reference: Amor et al., 2024, Nature Aging, doi:10.1038/s43587-023-00560-5

Evidence: Shown to be effective in ameliorating age-associated pathologies like liver fibrosis and metabolic dysfunction in mice.
Based on the conserved processes of cellular senescence and the adaptive immune system.
Reference: Ogrodnik et al., 2024, Cell, doi:10.1016/j.cell.2024.05.059

Evidence: No simple, non-invasive biomarker exists; assessment requires invasive tissue biopsies.
Reference: Ogrodnik et al., 2024, Cell, doi:10.1016/j.cell.2024.05.059

Evidence: Expected to be prohibitively high; similar therapies (CAR T-cell) can cost over $500,000 per dose.
Reference: Hernandez et al., 2018, JAMA Oncology, doi:10.1001/jamaoncol.2018.0977

Evidence: Well-established for hematopoietic disorders, but lacks evidence for a broad anti-aging indication. Some early trials show promise for frailty.
Reference: Tompkins et al., 2017, The Journals of Gerontology Series A: Biological Sciences and Medical Sciences, doi:10.1093/gerona/glx137

Evidence: Key consideration; autologous cells reduce rejection risk, but the procedure still carries risks of infection and other complications.
Reference: Waszczuk-Gajda et al., 2022, Journal of Clinical Medicine, doi:10.3390/jcm11123541

Evidence: A study found that transplanting hematopoietic stem cells from young to old mice extended lifespan by ~10%.
Reference: Guderyon et al., 2020, Aging Cell, doi:10.1111/acel.13110

Evidence: Broad benefits; can regenerate damaged tissue, modulate the immune system, and reduce inflammation.
Reference: Montserrat-Vazquez et al., 2022, npj Regenerative Medicine

Evidence: Highly conserved; stem cells play a fundamental role in tissue repair and regeneration across all complex life forms.
Reference: Bideau et al., 2021, Cellular and Molecular Life Sciences, doi:10.1007/s00018-021-03760-7

Evidence: No single, non-invasive biomarker exists for systemic anti-aging effects; efficacy measured by functional outcomes.
Reference: Moqri et al., 2023, Cell, doi:10.1016/j.cell.2023.08.003

Evidence: Prohibitively high due to specialized collection, processing, and administration.
Reference: Preussler et al., 2012, Biology of Blood and Marrow Transplantation (now Transplantation and Cellular Therapy), doi:10.1016/j.bbmt.2012.04.001

Evidence: Field is in its infancy; evidence is limited to specific applications like skin grafts and bladder augmentation.
Major concern; involves complex surgery with risks of infection and rejection.
Reference: Kuijer et al., 2007, Biomaterials, doi:10.1016/j.biomaterials.2007.06.003

Evidence: Not a preventative intervention; a therapeutic approach to restore function, so lifespan extension is not a direct endpoint.
Reference: Mao et al., 2015, Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, doi:10.1073/pnas.1508520112

Evidence: Potentially immense benefit, as a new organ can restore function completely lost due to disease or aging.
Reference: Gallico et al., 1984, The New England Journal of Medicine, doi:10.1056/NEJM198408163110706

Evidence: Based on fundamental, conserved biological and cellular mechanisms of tissue engineering.
Reference: Langer et al., 1993, Science, doi:10.1126/science.8493529

Evidence: Function of a new organ can be measured precisely using standard clinical biomarkers.
Reference: McAllister et al., 2009, The Lancet, doi:10.1016/S0140-6736(09)60248-8

Evidence: Prohibitively high due to complex, custom manufacturing and surgical procedures.
Reference: Jessop et al., 2015, Frontiers in Surgery, doi:10.3389/fsurg.2015.00052

Evidence: Earliest stages; the first successful transplants of genetically modified pig kidneys into living human patients occurred in 2024.
Reference: Kawai et al., 2025, New England Journal of Medicine, doi:10.1056/NEJMoa2412747

Evidence: Sizable concerns, including risk of hyperacute rejection and transmission of unknown zoonotic pathogens.
Reference: Fishman & Mueller, 2024, Emerging Infectious Diseases, doi:10.3201/eid3007.240273

Evidence: Not a preventative anti-aging intervention, but high potential to extend life by restoring organ function.
Reference: Riella, 2025, Journal of the American Society of Nephrology, doi:10.1681/ASN.0000000581

Evidence: Benefit is absolute for a person with a failing organ, potentially saving or extending a person's life.
Reference: Kawai et al., 2025, New England Journal of Medicine, doi:10.1056/NEJMoa2412747

Evidence: Underlying mechanisms of organ function and immune response are conserved, but significant physiological differences exist between pigs and humans.
Reference: Sykes & Sachs, 2022, Nature Reviews Nephrology, doi:10.1038/s41581-022-00624-6

Evidence: Organ function and rejection markers can be monitored using standard transplant protocols.
Reference: Westphal & Mannon, 2025, American Journal of Kidney Diseases, doi:10.1053/j.ajkd.2024.07.018

Evidence: Prohibitively high; a last-resort procedure requiring lifelong surveillance.
Reference: Anderson & Locke, 2024, Current Transplantation Reports, doi:10.1007/s40472-024-00455-3

Evidence: Limited and largely focused on aesthetic applications; no large-scale human data for systemic anti-aging effects.
Reference: Gupta et al., 2023, Journal of Cosmetic Dermatology, doi:10.1111/jocd.15869

Evidence: Advantage over stem cells as they are acellular, reducing risks like embolism; generally well-tolerated, but long-term systemic safety is unknown.
Reference: Xu et al., 2025, Signal Transduction and Targeted Therapy, doi:10.1038/s41392-025-02312-w

Evidence: Limited direct lifespan data, but has regenerative properties with a long-term vision for healthspan and longevity. A recent study reports reports ~12% median lifespan extension in aged mice treated with young plasma sEVs
Reference: Chen et al., 2024, Nature Aging, doi:10.1038/s43587-024-00612-4

Evidence: Possess regenerative, immunomodulatory, and anti-inflammatory properties; can stimulate collagen synthesis and promote muscle regeneration.
Reference: Sanz-Ros et al., 2022, Science Advances, doi:10.1126/sciadv.abq2226

Evidence: Based on intercellular communication, a fundamental and conserved biological process.
Reference: Kalluri et al., 2020, Science, doi:10.1126/science.aau6977

Evidence: Efficacy is often measured by downstream functional outcomes and changes in exosome cargo (miRNAs).
Reference: Arora et al., 2025, Scientific Reports, doi:10.1038/s41598-025-15814-y

Evidence: Prohibitive cost, making it a highly restricted therapy.
Reference: Wang et al., 2024, Clinical and Translational Science, doi:10.1111/cts.13904

Evidence: Entirely preclinical for a geroscience indication.
Reference: Kroemer et al., 2025, Cell, doi:10.1016/j.cell.2025.03.011

Evidence: Most significant barrier; use of viral vectors (AAVs) carries risks of off-target effects and life-threatening immune reactions.
Reference: Ronzitti et al., 2020, Frontiers in Immunology, doi:10.3389/fimmu.2020.00670

Evidence: Study showed elevating Klotho protein levels via gene therapy extended mouse lifespan by up to 30%.
Reference: Kurosu et al., 2005, Science, doi:10.1126/science.1112766

Evidence: Dramatic benefits including improved physical and cognitive function, larger muscle fibers, better bone density, and stimulated neurogenesis.
Reference: Roig-Soriano et al., 2025, Molecular Therapy, doi:10.1016/j.ymthe.2025.02.030

Evidence: Based on the fundamental principle of gene regulation; the Klotho gene is a conserved aging-suppressing gene in mammals.
Reference: Xu et al., 2015, Endocrine Reviews, doi:10.1210/er.2013-1079

Evidence: Strength; Klotho protein levels can be directly measured, and its effects on functional and epigenetic markers can be tracked.
Reference: Devaraj et al., 2012, American Journal of Clinical Pathology, doi:10.1309/AJCPGPMAF7SFRBO4

Evidence: Prohibitively inaccessible; among the most expensive medical interventions, with prices in the millions of dollars per dose.
Reference: Naddaf, 2022, Nature (news feature), doi:10.1038/d41586-022-04327-7

Evidence: A gene therapy trial for telomere biology disorders showed sustained telomere elongation without major safety concerns.
Reference: Myers KC et al., 2025, NEJM Evidence, doi:10.1056/EVIDoa2400252

Evidence: Primary concern is cancer risk, as uncontrolled telomerase expression can immortalize cells; transient modified RNA technique mitigates this risk.
Reference: Ramunas J et al., 2015, FASEB Journal, doi:10.1096/fj.14-259531

Evidence: Modified RNA therapy lengthened telomeres in cultured human cells, allowing them to divide more times.
Reference: Ramunas J et al., 2015, FASEB Journal, doi:10.1096/fj.14-259531

Evidence: Modified RNA therapy increased proliferation of cultured human muscle and skin cells, "turning back the clock" on a cellular level.
Reference: Ramunas J et al., 2015, FASEB Journal, doi:10.1096/fj.14-259531

Evidence: Based on a fundamental and conserved biological process involving telomeres and telomerase ensuring chromosome integrity.
Reference: Blackburn EH et al., 2006, Nature Medicine, doi:10.1038/nm1006-1133

Evidence: Telomere length itself is a direct and precise biomarker of the intervention's effect.
Reference: Fasching CL, 2018, Critical Reviews in Clinical Laboratory Sciences, doi:10.1080/10408363.2018.1504274

Evidence: Prohibitively high; early gene therapy trials were exceptionally expensive.
Reference: Naddaf M, 2022, Nature (News Feature), doi:10.1038/d41586-022-04327-7

Evidence: Probiotics show moderate effects on immune function in older adults; one pilot trial of a symbiotic reversed biological age.
Reference: Fitzgerald et al., 2021, Aging (Albany NY), doi:10.18632/aging.202913

Evidence: Excellent safety for diet-based modulation and many probiotics; FMT carries risks of complications and pathogen transmission.
Reference: DeFilipp et al., 2019, New England Journal of Medicine, doi:10.1056/NEJMoa1910437

Evidence: Fecal microbiota transplantation (FMT) from young to old mice extends lifespan and improves healthspan.
Reference: Bárcena et al., 2019, Nature Medicine, doi:10.1038/s41591-019-0504-5

Evidence: Can reduce chronic inflammation ("inflammaging"), improve metabolic health, and alleviate depression/anxiety-like behaviors in aged mice.
Reference: Parker et al., 2022, Microbiome, doi:10.1186/s40168-022-01243-w

Evidence: The interaction between a host and its microbial ecosystem is a highly conserved biological mechanism.
Reference: Wilde et al., 2024, Science, doi:10.1126/science.adi3338

Evidence: Microbiota composition can be assessed, but these are not yet standardized biomarkers for routine geroscience trials.
Reference: Xu et al., 2024, Microbiome Research Reports, doi:10.20517/mrr.2023.68

Evidence: Lifestyle changes and many probiotics are low-cost; however, therapies like FMT can be very expensive.
Reference: Wynn et al., 2023, Cureus, doi:10.7759/cureus.35116

Evidence: A large trial (ASPREE) found daily low-dose aspirin did not prolong healthy living in older adults and increased bleeding risk.
Reference: McNeil et al., 2018, New England Journal of Medicine, 10.1056/NEJMoa1800722

Evidence: Significant risks of side effects, including gastrointestinal bleeding and kidney problems.
Reference: Harirforoosh et al., 2013, Journal of Pharmacy & Pharmaceutical Sciences, 10.18433/J3VW2F

Evidence: Conflicting data; one meta-analysis showed lifespan increase, but the NIA ITP study found no increase for aspirin in mice.
Reducing inflammation would have broad benefits; drugs like NSAIDs also activate NRF2, a master regulator of cellular homeostasis.
Reference: Eisenstein et al., 2022, Immunity, 10.1016/j.immuni.2022.04.015

Evidence: The inflammatory response is a deeply conserved biological mechanism.
Reference: Medzhitov, 2008, Nature, 10.1038/nature07201

Evidence: Inflammatory markers like IL-6 and hs-CRP are routinely measured in clinical practice, making it easy to track effects.
Reference: Ridker, 2016, Circulation Research, 10.1161/CIRCRESAHA.115.306656

Evidence: Highly accessible; many drugs are available over-the-counter and are very low cost.
Reference: Grootendorst et al., 2005, Health Services Research, 10.1111/j.1475-6773.2005.00420.x

Evidence: Very limited; a small trial in Alzheimer's patients showed some functional but no cognitive benefits; FDA cautioned against it as "unproven".
Reference: Sha et al., 2019, JAMA Neurology, doi:10.1001/jamaneurol.2018.3288

Evidence: Significant concerns, including the risk of infection and adverse immune reactions.
Reference: Pandey et al., 2012, Transfusion, doi:10.1111/j.1537-2995.2012.03663.x

Evidence: Lack of specific data on lifespan extension from parabiosis experiments, with some studies showing no benefit.
Reference: Yankova et al., 2022, Rejuvenation Research, doi:10.1089/rej.2022.0029

Evidence: Early experiments suggested rejuvenation of aged tissues, but later studies showed old blood was more detrimental than young blood was beneficial.
Reference: Rebo et al., 2016, Nature Communications, doi:10.1038/ncomms13363

Evidence: Age-related changes in the blood and their effects on tissues are conserved across mammals.
Reference: Lagunas-Rangel, 2024, npj Aging and Mechanisms of Disease, doi:10.1038/s41514-024-00166-0

Evidence: Age-related changes in plasma proteins and metabolites have been investigated as potential biomarkers.
Reference: Lehallier et al., 2019, Nature Medicine, doi:10.1038/s41591-019-0673-2

Evidence: Expensive with questionable benefits; limited availability and regulatory restrictions.
Reference: Hofmann, 2018, Transfusion Medicine and Hemotherapy, doi:10.1159/000481828

Evidence: A single human trial showed therapeutic plasma exchange (TPE) significantly lowered biological age, providing a powerful proof-of-concept that needs replication.
TPE is an FDA-approved procedure with a known and generally well-managed safety profile; most side effects are mild-to-moderate.
Reference: Shemin et al., 2007, Journal of Clinical Apheresis, 10.1002/jca.20143

Evidence: A preclinical study showed that diluting old plasma was more effective than adding young plasma at rejuvenating multiple tissues in mice.
Reference: Mehdipour et al., 2020, Aging (Albany NY), 10.18632/aging.103418

Evidence: Benefits include rejuvenation of muscle and liver, and promotion of better hippocampal neurogenesis in mice.
Reference: Mehdipour et al., 2020, Aging (Albany NY), 10.18632/aging.103418

Evidence: Based on the conserved concept that aging is driven by an accumulation of detrimental molecular factors in the blood.
Reference: Lagunas-Rangel et al., 2024, npj Aging Mechanisms of Disease, 10.1038/s41514-024-00166-0

Evidence: Epigenetic clocks provide a direct and quantifiable measure of biological age reversal, used successfully in a human trial.
Reference: Fuentealba et al., 2025, Aging Cell, 10.1111/acel.70103

Evidence: Significant barrier; cost is high, making it highly inaccessible for broad preventative use.
Reference: Winters et al., 2011, BMC Health Services Research, 10.1186/1472-6963-11-101
